content.question:
For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

A student is given <math alttext="50.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of a solution of <math alttext="N a 2 C O 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> of unknown concentration. To determine the concentration of the solution, the student mixes the solution with excess <math alttext="1.0 molar C a, open parenthesis, N O 3, close parenthesis, 2, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><msub><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Ca(NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mtext></mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, causing a precipitate to form. The balanced equation for the reaction is shown below.

<math alttext="N a 2 C O 3, aqueous plus C a, open parenthesis, N O 3, close parenthesis, 2, aqueous, reacts to produce, 2 N a N O 3, aqueous plus C a C O 3, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>Ca</mtext><msub><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>(NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>)</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>NaNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>CaCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

(a) Write the net ionic equation for the reaction that occurs when the solutions of <math alttext="N a 2 C O 3" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> and <math alttext="C a, open parenthesis, N O 3, close parenthesis, 2 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext></mtext><mtext>Ca</mtext><msub><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>(NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>)</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> are mixed.

frqParts.text:
For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

A student is given <math alttext="50.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of a solution of <math alttext="N a 2 C O 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> of unknown concentration. To determine the concentration of the solution, the student mixes the solution with excess <math alttext="1.0 molar C a, open parenthesis, N O 3, close parenthesis, 2, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><msub><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Ca(NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mtext></mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, causing a precipitate to form. The balanced equation for the reaction is shown below.

<math alttext="N a 2 C O 3, aqueous plus C a, open parenthesis, N O 3, close parenthesis, 2, aqueous, reacts to produce, 2 N a N O 3, aqueous plus C a C O 3, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>Ca</mtext><msub><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>(NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>)</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>NaNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>CaCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

(a) Write the net ionic equation for the reaction that occurs when the solutions of <math alttext="N a 2 C O 3" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> and <math alttext="C a, open parenthesis, N O 3, close parenthesis, 2 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext></mtext><mtext>Ca</mtext><msub><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>(NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>)</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> are mixed.
(b) The diagram below is incomplete. Draw in the species needed to accurately represent the major ionic species remaining in the solution after the reaction has been completed.

The student filters and dries the precipitate of <math alttext="C a C O 3 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> (molar mass <math alttext="100.1 grams per mole" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100.1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>g/mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) and records the data in the table below.

Volume of <math alttext="N a 2 C O 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> solution
 <math alttext="50.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

Volume of <math alttext="1.0 molar C a, open parenthesis, N O 3, close parenthesis, 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mtext></mtext><msub><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>Ca(NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>)</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> added
 <math alttext="100.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

Mass of <math alttext="C a C O 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> precipitate collected
 <math alttext="0.93 gram" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>0.93</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></math>

(c) Determine the number of moles of <math alttext="N a 2 C O 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> in the original <math alttext="50.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of solution.

(d) The student realizes that the precipitate was not completely dried and claims that as a result, the calculated <math alttext="N a 2 C O 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> molarity is too low. Do you agree with the student’s claim? Justify your answer.
(e) After the precipitate forms and is filtered, the liquid that passed through the filter is tested to see if it can conduct electricity. What would be observed? Justify your answer.

The student decides to determine the molarity of the same <math alttext="N a 2 C O 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> solution using a second method. When <math alttext="N a 2 C O 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is dissolved in water, <math alttext="C O 3 with a negative 2 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math> hydrolyzes to form <math alttext="H C O 3 with a negative one charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>, as shown by the following equation.

<math alttext="C O 3 with a negative 2 charge, aqueous, plus H 2 O liquid, is in equilibrium with H C O 3 with a negative one charge, aqueous plus O H with a negative one charge, aqueous, K sub b equals, the fraction with numerator, the molar concentration of H C O 3 with a negative one charge, times, the molar concentration of O H with a negative one charge, and denominator, the molar concentration of C O 3 with a negative 2 charge, equals, 2.1 times 10 to the negative 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>(</mtext><mi>l</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>⇄</mo><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mtd><mtd><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>[</mo><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>]</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>]</mo></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>2.1</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>

(f) The student decides to first determine <math alttext="the molar concentration of O H with a negative one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in the solution, then use that result to calculate the initial concentration of <math alttext="C O 3 with a negative 2 charge, aqueous " overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>.

(i) Identify a laboratory method (not titration) that the student could use to collect data to determine <math alttext="the molar concentration of O H with a negative one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in the solution.

(ii) Explain how the student could use the measured value in part (f)(i) to calculate the initial concentration of <math alttext="C O 3 with a negative 2 charge, aqueous " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. (Do not do any numerical calculations.)

(g) In the original <math alttext="N a 2 C O 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> solution at equilibrium, is the concentration of <math alttext="H C O 3 with a negative one charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> greater than, less than, or equal to the concentration of <math alttext="C O 3 with a negative 2 charge, aqueous " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Justify your answer.

(h) The student needs to make a <math alttext="C O 3 with a negative 2 charge, H C O 3 with a negative one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>/</mo><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> buffer. Is the <math alttext="N a 2 C O 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> solution suitable for making a buffer with a <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Explain why or why not.

skill.text: 2.B: Formulate a hypothesis or predict the results of an experiment.
